ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was a wonderful deep-dive into these two authors and these two specific works. I gained skills in deep-reading and political philosophy analysis.

I learned the core of Tocqueville and Mill's views on democracy and also how they relate to issues of governance, human nature, and culture. I advanced my ability to do close reading of a text and to draw comparisons between them.

While this class focuses on Tocqueville and Mill, you learn how to read works of political theory and write analytically about them. I was also glad to learn about 19th century political theory in general and discuss some of the questions that many philosophers grappled with at the time. Our class was a perfect combination of lecture and discussion. While professor Wilford contextualized readings and provided relevant information about Tocqueville or Mill during her lectures, we were able to also bring up and discuss our own questions.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought this class was really good. I'm not sure there is much I would say that could be improvements.

Strengths: Dr. Wilford is highly knowledgeable, pushes you to really be precise in understanding an author's argument, and advances both charitable but exact interpretations of authors' arguments.
Weaknesses: Sometimes pacing could be slow and as a result we were behind on the following week's readings

You get an opportunity to focus on a few authors, which I think is rare in the Yale Humanities and Political Science departments. I appreciated having weeks to explore Tocqueviile and Mill's writings, instead of only spending a week on each. We were able to talk about the readings line by line, rather than talking abstractly about vague ideas.  I think this structure of the class actually encouraged us to do all the readings for each class. 

The only weakness I can think of is that we sometimes didn't get to discuss all of our readings in class. I know that some professors stick to the syllabus, but I actually appreciated how professor Wilford amended it. Although we didn't get to read Mill's "Civilizations" essay, I think I know all the works we did read and discussed very well.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Wilford did a wonderful job of engaging the class despite the fact that we were online.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course, even if you haven't taken a political philosophy course. Professor Wilford did an excellent job of laying out the structure and general themes of chapters, and it allowed for really interesting discussions.

Absolutely. Dr. Wilford is a knowledgeable educator and a true leader of classroom discussion. She facilitates not only the expansion of students' knowledge, but also the challenging of their viewpoints through her questions. I learned about seminal theorists and I truly do not think I could have gained a more detailed understanding of them outside of Dr. Wilford.
Yes! If you are interested in political theory, you must take this class.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
